pros: The digital marketing team is very forward-thinking. A great team to be a part of.
cons: My focus is generally shifted to short-term thinking; probably because my role doesn't always require me to think longer term. This is a con for me because my strengths come in when I think about things more broadly.
advice_to_mgmt: Management is doing a great job in shifting the culture and moving forward.

pros: Great co-workers and free pop.
cons: Some of the lowest pay in industry.
advice_to_mgmt: Value your better salespeople. At least pretend you care?

review_title: Benefits are amazing but upper management doesn’t want to pay their sales team
years_at_company: Benefits are amazing but upper management doesn’t want to pay their sales team
pros:
Benefits
Work life balance
Great colleagues
Client relationships
With the right manager, you can be independent
cons:
Growth Targets are aggressive and unattainable
Comp plan is set up so that it’s best to be only at 100%
In 2019 you have contracts from 2017 in your base
Some managers micromanage
Lots of admin duties
advice_to_mgmt: Work with your sales team to make better targets. Restructure the commission plan so that you get paid a fair rate if you are under 100 percent. Pam is toxic for the team and will cause good people to leave just so they don’t have to work for her.

pros: Global brand, good work/life balance, passionate people.
cons: Top heavy management, not tech focused, new CEO is very political, too many management layers, mediocre talent.
advice_to_mgmt: Organizational restructuring (again), invest in a real tech stack, focus on career development and mentorship.

pros: Stimulating subject matter & industry.
cons: Little opportunity for advancement. High turnover as a result. No training.
advice_to_mgmt: Invest more in employees.

pros: For most of my time there - innovation, creativity, lots of hard-working, smart people with passion for the business. Used to have great culture and people. Used to be the "best place I had ever worked professionally, financially, and personally," which was their tagline. But dramatic changes in recent years have changed this.
cons: The company has undergone dramatic changes since the changing of the CEO hired in late 2015. She was great, but all leadership changed, and the culture changed accordingly. It has significantly impacted the culture and the drive of the employees.

pros: Great people and good work life balance
cons: Some uncertainty in the future of the business

pros: Great people, great benefits, new office, amazing content.

pros: good people good atmosphere

pros: Quality operations and appreciation for staff.

pros: product is great. people are great. PTO is great (27 PTO days per year), I mean common. maternity leave is good.

pros: Amazing Content and Photographers. Dedicated and loyal staff.
cons: Sr. Management is smart but clueless. Very out of touch with industry needs and trends and are often late to market with improvements or "innovations". They have completely lost their position as market leaders - they are definitely followers.
advice_to_mgmt: Get out of your offices and start getting in front of clients. Listen to them.

pros: Flexibility of working from home.
cons: The ICE position is commission only and many of the leads are recycled.

pros: Benefits are ok. There seems to be a real effort by some in leadership to open the lines of communication. Many of the people manager level and below truly care about their jobs and will help you in any way they can.
cons: Pay is far below market standard. There is also no professional development. If you're looking for a place that is going to take your skillset and help you develop, this is not your place. Director and above do not view that as important and will prevent you from doing anything to enhance your skills. There seems to be the Amazon mentality creeping in of having people come in for 2-3 years, they burn out and bring in the next. However they don't offer the benefits or pay commensurate to attract the talent level needed to progress a company. There is also a severe problem with people who are terrible at their jobs being protected by upper management. Maybe see what the common denominator is on certain problems and fix that instead of paying lip service to the concerns of effective people.
advice_to_mgmt: Your people are valuable and not stupid. They recognize when someone plays favorites with their team. You're losing a lot of very talented people because of ineffective leadership is ruining a team that was once considered extremely effective.

pros: Catered lunch once a month. Wow, how lucky we are.
cons:
-Absolutely no opportunities for growth or development.
-Salary is 20k under median income in Chicago, and company has decided not to give raises this year (would have only been about 0.80 raise anyway.) Be prepared to ask yourself questions like "Do I eat tonight or be late on rent?" "Can I really afford a loaf of bread right now?" "What am I doing with my life?"
-Management does not care about you, your goals, or your professional development. They'll say they are "working on it," but that's usually just a way to end the conversation.
-No work/life balance if you're starting as a CSM. You'll work 10-7pm with no flexibility. You'll go to work, go home to sleep, and then go back to work. That's your life.
advice_to_mgmt: What's the point, they don't listen or care.

review_title: Best place to work for. Period.
years_at_company: Best place to work for. Period.
pros: Lots of money to be made. Everyone usually hits their year goal or exceeds. No matter how new you are.
cons: None! Keep up the great work of being a leader in the market! Some work from home wouldn't be bad.

pros: Great and fascinating products and technology stack, and the nicest people you will ever work with. You get plenty of space to do your own thing.
cons: The downside of "space to do your own thing" is that it's very easy to feel alone, isolated and lost. Very difficult to move up the ladder. Many senior leadership have been there a *long* time so there is a fair bit of myopia about limitations/problems. Management has good intentions to make things better but when I left (July 2017) there had not been much progress.
advice_to_mgmt: Walk the talk of providing support and *really listening* (not just providing rote and empty rituals of listening).

pros: great creative team and cutting edge technology, management always encourages development and furthering your career, pay is on point with other similar companies

advice_to_mgmt: listen to employees and don't rest on your laurels, keep the content fresh and up to date with competitors collections

advice_to_mgmt: No advice.

review_title: Company is still years behind. You'd be better off looking elsewhere
years_at_company: Company is still years behind. You'd be better off looking elsewhere
pros:
- Work/Life Balance: For the most part, this is a 40 hour job. If you work any more than this amount, it's definitely not worth it
- Top-down management style. Directors and above have a cushy life
cons:
- Top-down management style. A lot of people telling the "worker bees" what to do, but not enough "do-ers" who actually get the work done
- No career path
- Lack of consistency across various organizations - people often are confused about goals and company strategy
- Company doesn't reward the right behavior
advice_to_mgmt: Simply a lack of consistency, transparency, and focus. It's great that the company implemented employee surveys, but leadership does a poor job at interpreting the results and making the proper changes. For example, when we ask for more transparency, we don't want more "All Hands" meetings that talk about nothing. When it comes to important decisions, things are kept close to the vest and leads to utter confusion. I can't honestly recommend this place to anyone within my network.
